summary: Background La Crosse virus (LACV), family Bunyaviridae, was first identified as a human pathogen in 1960 after its isolation from a 4 year-old girl with fatal encephalitis in La Crosse, Wisconsin. the virus is a major cause of pediatric encephalitis in North America and infects up to 300,000 persons each year of which 70–130 result in severe disease of the central nervous system (CNS) virus is transmitted by hardwood forest dwelling mosquitoes, Aedes triseriatus. virus can be maintained in the mosquito population in absence of vertebrate hosts by transovarial (vertical) transmission, thus allowing the virus to over-winter in mosquito eggs. in humans, the majority of infections are mild and attributed to the "flu" or "summer cold" the majority of infections are mild and attributed to the "flu" or "summer cold" with an estimated 300,000 infections annually. there are only 70–130 serious cases reported. children who recover from severe La Crosse encephalitis may have significantly lower IQ scores than expected. a high prevalence (60% of those tested) of attention-deficit-hyperactivity disorder is also common in survivors [23]. Projected lifelong economic costs associated with neurologic sequelae range from $48,775 – 3,090,398 per case. rhesus monkeys were chosen because they are susceptible to a variety of neurotropic arboviruses, including flaviviruses. rhesus monkeys were infected intramuscularly or subcutaneously with a mosquito or human isolate of LACV. infection did not result in viremia, disease, or significant changes in blood chemistries or cell counts. virus was detected in serum on days 1–3, but rarely on subsequent days even in moribund mice. by day three, virus distribution was widespread and could be found in most tissues sampled. highest virus titers detected were present in nasal turbinates, brain, and spinal cord. aPercent of mice positive by plaque assay represented by shading: 100% black, 66% dark gray, 33% light gray, 0% no data entry. Mean virus titer calculated only for virus positive tissues. the ID50 titers (1.5 and 1.6 log10 PFU for the IN and IP routes, respectively) were slightly lower than the LD50 titers. LACV is highly virulent in mice inoculated by either the intraperitoneal (IP) or intranasal (IN) route. changes in percent survival did not occur after day 10. the most extensive lesions occurred in the medulla oblongata. the most extensive lesions occurred in the medulla oblongata. hematoxylin counterstain X200. (F) TUNEL positive (brown) apoptotic bodies in the thalamus. hematoxylin counterstain X200. (F) apoptotic bodies in the thalamus. la crosse viral antigen in a punctate pattern in neurons (arrows) in the locus coeruleus. plasmacytosis in the spleen was observed on days 4–6. lymphoid atrophy was only observed on days 3–4 post-infection. viral antigen was detected in the olfactory bulb of the brain, thalamus, cerebrum, medulla oblongata, and spinal cord. perivascular cuffing was seen in a few areas and single cell necrosis was seen in areas stained positive for viral antigen. by day 6, viral infection in the CNS was widespread and extensive throughout all regions of the brain and spinal cord. rhesus monkeys were inoculated with 105 PFU of biologically cloned human or mosquito LACV (LACV/human/1978-clone, LACV/mosquito/1978-clone) virus was present at a low titer in lymph nodes on days 6, 8, and 12, but virus replication in these tissues could not be identified by IHC staining. ous neutralizing antibody titer on indicated day (reciprocal PRNT60)c Virus and inoculation route Monkey # Temp. (°F)a Lymph node virus titersb -7 0 2 4 6 8 10 12 14 14 21 28 GMTd (Day 28) Human/1978/clone (SQ) DB00 2.3 (day 12) 5 5 5 5 13 22 166 620 1465 2924 2186 DB1Z 5 5 5 temperatures outside normal range (98–102.7 F) indicated by day in parenthesis, normal values left blank. b Lymph nodes were collected on days 4, 6, 8, and 12 for virus titer and IHC staining. the majority of monkeys experienced a slight anemia after day 6. this may be associated with the overnight fast in preparation for anesthesia prior to each blood collection. this analysis suggests that infection of major organs such as liver was minimal or absent. (F) TUNEL positive (brown) apoptotic bodies in the thalamus. cells in mitral cell layer (arrow) and granule cell layer (arrowhead) of main olfactory bulb. viral antigen was detected in the olfactory bulb of the brain, thalamus, cerebrum, medulla oblongata, and spinal cord. on day 5, viral antigen could be detected in all sample brain regions. ing was seen in a few areas and single cell necrosis was seen in areas stained positive for viral antigen. only small foci of antigen were seen in the spinal cord of one mouse suggesting brain infection proceeds spinal cord infection. by day 6, viral infection in the CNS was widespread and extensive throughout all regions of the brain and spinal cord. rhesus monkeys were inoculated with 105 PFU of biologically cloned (terminally diluted) human or mosquito LACV (LACV/human/1978-clone, LACV/mosquito/1978-clone, LACV/mosquito/1978-clone) viremia was present at a low titer in lymph nodes on days 6, 8, and 12, but virus replication in these tissues could not be identified by IHC staining 620 1465 2924 2186 DB1Z 5 5 5 5 5 24 137 126 332 679 1412 CL74 5 5 5 5 5 5 5 31 199 546 1370 1374 DBCV 5 5 5 5 5 5 6 43 246 234 1684 4022 Human/1978/clone (IM) DB9J 5 5 5 5 5 5 5 5 66 343 1011 603 1776 1906 DB5C 1.4 (day 12) 5 5 5 5 5 0H 13 13 18 13 15 28 130 516 1566 1134 687 DA9F 102.9 (day -7) 0.7 (day 8) 5 5 5 5 5 11 94 1833 3189 3656 2762 a Rectal temperature collected at time of blood draw. temperatures outside normal range (98–102.7 F) indicated by day in parenthesis, normal values left blank. LACV/mosquito/1978-cl at 101 or 103 PFU subcutaneously. blood was collected on days 0, 21, 28, and 42. serum neutralizing antibody titers were 1:355 and 1:82 for the 101 or 103 PFU dose groups. mice can be used to evaluate both level of attenuation and immunogenicity of candidate vaccine viruses. previous studies in suckling mice inoculated with a mosquito isolate of LACV demonstrated that viral antigen was detected in the cytoplasm of striated muscles, the interscapular brown fat, and the endothelial and smooth muscle cells of small arteries and veins. 2 of 62 mice tested had detectable virus within the brain without detectable virus in the nasal cavity. the LD50 and ID50 were almost identical by either route by inoculation. it is possible that infectious virus is present in water collections containing Aedes mosquito larvae. in the weanling mouse, LACV infects predominantly neurons with spread in a rostral to caudal direction eventually reaching the lumbar spinal region. in both mice and humans, virus has been detected in the cerebral cortex, however infection appears more widespread in the mouse CNS. rhesus monkeys in the current study experienced a subclinical infection without the development of systemic disease or neurologic symptoms. all monkeys were infected with LACV and developed neutralizing antibody responses, even after inoculation with as little as 10 PFU. it is still unclear why so many human LACV infections remain asymptomatic. toxic T lymphocytes (HLA-B49) had a greater relative risk of developing seizures. infected individuals with HLA-DR5 had a lower relative risk of developing seizures. the LD50 and ID50 are similar, indicating most infections lead to a lethal outcome at this age. OptiPROTMSFM medium (Invitrogen) supplemented with 4 mM L-glutamine. LACV/human/1960 was isolated from post-mortem brain tissue collected from a Minnesota patient hospitalized in La Crosse, Wisconsin. Biological clones were generated by terminal dilution in Vero cells. the Swiss Webster mice were inoculated with 1 or 100 LD50 in a volume of 100 l [6]. the tissues indicated in Table 1 were collected individually (3 mice per day for 6 days at each dose of virus), weighed, homogenized in L15 with SPG buffer. all mice were carefully observed twice daily for clinical disease including tremors and limb paralysis. tissues collected for pathology were fixed in 10% neutral buffered formalin (NBF) sections were prepared at 4–5 (m) when bone was present in the tissue, as with muscle, nasal cavity, and spinal cord, tissues were decalcified using Immunocal. sections were stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) the primary antibody, rabbit anti-human CD3, was used at a dilution of 1:300. slides were stream hydrated with citrate buffer for 20 minutes. rhesus monkeys (n = 4) were inoculated with 101 or 103 PFU LACV/mosquito/1978-clone subcutaneously. blood samples were collected on days 0, 21, 28, and 42 post inoculation for neutralizing antibody titration. LACV/human/1960 was isolated from post-mortem brain tissue collected from a Minnesota patient hospitalized in La Crosse, Wisconsin and passaged two times in C6/36 cells. Biological clones were generated by terminal dilution in Vero cell cultures. the tissues indicated in Table 1 were collected individually (3 mice per day for 6 days at each dose of virus), weighed, homogenized in L15 with SPG buffer (final concentration 218 mM sucrose, 6 mM L-glutamic acid, 3.8 mM dibasic potassium phosphate, pH 7.2) mice were carefully observed twice daily for clinical disease including tremors and limb paralysis. sections were fixed in 10% neutral buffered formalin (NBF) for a minimum of 72 hours. tissue was decalcified using Immunocal (Decal Chemical Corp. Tallman, NY) sections were deparaffinized with xylene and washed with deionized water. a serial section was saved for immunohistochemical staining. the primary antibody, rabbit anti-human CD3, was used at a dilution of 1:300. slides were stream hydrated with citrate buffer for 20 minutes. each virus was inoculated intramuscularly (n = 4) or subcutaneously (n = 4). blood samples were collected on days 0, 21, 28, and 42 post inoculation for neutralizing antibody titration. test sera were heat inactivated (56°C for 30 minutes) and serial 2-fold dilutions beginning at 1:5 or 1:10 were prepared in OptiMEM. authors wish to thank Mark Hughs for the LACV/human/1978 and Bob Tesh for the LACV/mosquito/1978 and LACV/human/1960 stocks.
